As Meta announces it's spending more money, as Microsoft announces, Alphabet announces it's spending more money, I think investors are wise to keep in mind how that money spreads through the market and through the economy because that might be, you know, as you say, follow the money as you're you're picking out your investments.

RS: What else would you say, stock wise, that you're focused on or that you've been focused on or investors should be looking at heading into next week?

BS: We have a busy earning season, but lack of the same level of marquee names.

I think one interesting one would be Palantir (PLTR). It's coming out early next week. It's become a high profile AI play, so look for more information there.

And then (AMD) is reporting next week as well. So you have another chip provider, which will which will play into that.

On the economic calendar, I think the most interesting report is one that's not going to happen.

We're not going to get a jobs report as we would have otherwise expected next week, with the government shutdown reaching, I think, day 31 at this point. Very, very likely that it's going to become the longest shutdown in US history.

Not really an end in sight for that. And one of the impacts on Wall Street is the lack of the economic news. So even as the Fed is trying to figure out what the economy is doing, we don't really have the same kind of information.

I mean, we're going to get the ADP report, we're going to get JOLTS, but we're not going to get the traditional jobs report.

And it seems likely that we might not ever get that data, at least not in the form that we're used to because of the government shutdown, they weren't gathering the data in the same way they were before.

So it might not be able to be reconstructed after the fact once we we get the government reopened.

So to a certain extent, we're gonna be flying a little blind, at least through a haze, in the near term economically. So it's just a a factor to keep in mind.

RS: And what else should investors be thinking about? We had NVIDIA (NVDA) crossing a threshold. Anything you would wanna say about NVIDIA and what that portends for investing in general?

BS: Topped $5 trillion, became the first $5,000,000,000,000 company.

It it backed off a little bit, so I think it's hovering just below that level right now. I think the most interesting aspect of that is just how quickly it went from 4,000,000,000,000 to to 5,000,000,000,000.

It was hundred and ten days. So between three and four months.

RS: Is that because this time is different, Brian?

BS: That's the question being asked. Right? One of the interesting things about Meta is, Meta's drop took it below the performance of the S&P 500 (SP500).

So after falling the the 11% after earnings, the stock is now underperforming the S&P 500. It was overperforming. Meanwhile, a lot of these other tech and and Mag 7 stocks are at new highs. So those valuation concerns are are still there.

I think that's one of the reasons why the CapEx spending has become such a big topic is there's a lot of money going out and and not a whole lot coming in yet for a lot of these companies.

And so when you're talking about the debate on whether or not AI is a bubble and things like that, I think that those are the factors that are playing into it.

And when you get to the conversation, is it different this time? I think that's the heart of that debate.

data.title: Garmin: Strong Q3 But The Stock Looks Fully Priced
data.description:
Back in February 2025, I downgraded my initial bullish recommendation to a hold on Garmin Ltd. (GRMN) because although the company delivered record results in FY2024, the stock price had increased by 108% within a year's time. This put the valuation at a premium, and at the same time I was cautious of the impact of increased competition within its Fitness segment and continuous losses with the Auto Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) segment. Since then, the stock has declined by about 4.8%, and Garmin has now reported its Q3 2025 results. After reviewing its latest Q3 2025 results, my view remains that although Garmin continues to perform well as a business, at current valuation levels, I still see the stock as fairly valued rather than a clear bargain. Therefore, for long-term investors, I think it makes sense to continue holding and waiting for a better price entry point.

Q3 2025 earnings and long-term outlook

Over the last three financial years, since FY2022, Garmin has been increasing its top and bottom line results consecutively and appears to be on its way to continue to do this in FY2025 after delivering a strong Q3 2025. From a business perspective, Garmin’s strength remains its diversification. The Fitness segment pushed up results, led the way again with 30% year-over-year (YoY) growth, supported by continued demand for high-end smartwatches and new launches. We can see that its trailing twelve month revenue (TTM) is $6.9 billion and net income is $1.57 billion, which are both higher than the results in FY2024.

In Q3 2025, the company generated $1.77 billion in revenue, which was an increase of 12% YoY. Its operating income grew by 4% to $457 million, and its operating margin was 25.8%. Its EPS was in line with expectations at $1.99, and revenue fell slightly under expectations, by $24.2 million.

The company has generated strong results in the first half of the year, which it has now backed up by another upward trending quarter. Due to the strong performance, it has increased its FY 2025 guidance. It is now expecting annual revenue of $7.1 billion and EPS of $8.15. The Auto OEM segment, similar to my previous update, continues to negatively impact overall results with a negative revenue of 2% drop in revenue YoY. Management has acknowledged these challenges in the earnings call and hinted that partnerships or a strategic review might be on the table if performance does not improve.

Balance sheet and cash flow

Garmin has a strong balance sheet, which remains one of the company’s biggest advantages. As of Q3 2025, Garmin has $2.59 billion in cash compared to only $189.7 million in total debt, which gives it a very low debt-to-equity ratio of just 2.3%. Looking at the company's liquidity, we can see it has a current ratio of 3.01 and a quick ratio of 1.87. This gives a clear indication that the company has enough short-term assets to cover its obligations.

If we look at the company's annual levered free cash flow, we can see that it has been upward trending over the last three financial years, although TTM is lower than the previous year at $908.8 million. The positive cash flow supports the company's ability to reward shareholders and reinvest in the organisation. The company's dividend has been growing over the previous seven years and has a forward annual payout of $3.60. In addition, it also has a share repurchase program.

Valuation

At $214.97 per share, Garmin is still a strong company, but the stock looks fairly priced. It has fallen from its high of $259 earlier this month, yet remains up over the past year. Even after the recent drop in stock price, the forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio is 26.94, which is still 12% higher than its five year average. In the table below, we can see that the company continues to run efficiently, it earns healthy profits with a 58.94% gross margin and has a 23.21% net margin. It has also been generating returns over the long run that beat the S&P 500 returns, which is what an investor wants to see. However, growth has started to slow a bit. Revenue is still rising at high double digit growth YoY, but its free cash flow fell by 27.41% as Garmin invests more in new products and operations. Overall, investors are paying a premium for a reliable, well-run business. However, this limits the upside potential for investors looking to add shares at the current price.

Risks

While Garmin is a large billion dollar company with growing financials, there are still a number of risks to think about as a potential investor. In its Fitness and wearables market, there is fierce competition from giants like Apple (AAPL) and Samsung (OTCPK:SSNLF), amongst many smaller competitors too. The increase in competition can have a negative impact on the company's profitability and growth potential. We've seen that its Auto OEM segment continues to generate losses, which could negatively impact the company's overall performance if it continues. Another issue is that Garmin is heavily dependent on manufacturing activities in Taiwan running smoothly, with more than 90% of Garmin’s manufacturing facilities based there. This is a politically sensitive area and could negatively impact the businesses if tensions increase and potentially disrupt operations.

Final thoughts

Garmin has reported another strong financial quarter and increased its FY 2025 guideline, it appears to be on its way to improve its top and bottom line for consecutive financial years. It has very diverse business segments, which brings both strengths and weaknesses to the business. Long term investors have seen strong returns over the last decade, significantly beating the S&P 500 over the last decade. However, the stock’s current premium valuation and uncertainties, including increased competition, its underperforming Auto OEM segment, and reliance on a politically sensitive region for manufacturing, keep me cautious. Therefore, I would maintain a Hold rating and wait for a better entry price entry or a clearer visibility on Auto OEM recovery and its position within a growing competitive consumer market.

data.title: Intel: The Market Is Taking The Recovery Hopium Way Too Far
data.description:
Intel: Finally Out Of The Doghouse?

Perennial underperformer Intel Corporation (INTC) appears to have finally hammered its way out of the doghouse, as the stock mounted a phenomenal 1Y return of >80%, beating back confidently against the deafening pessimistic clamor, and punishing those that had the temerity to short the stock at the lows, at just below the $19 level.

I've certainly not expected such a breakthrough in bullish sentiments for the erstwhile king of semis, even though its market cap has recovered to just over the $190 billion mark. However, that's miles and miles away from Nvidia's recent $5 trillion market valuation (NVDA) achievement, as semiconductor investors welcome the next phase in this unprecedented AI infrastructure buildout that could stretch through the rest of the decade.

As for Intel, bullish investors who held on to their conviction and added more through the start of this year will likely assert that Intel's worst malaise is behind us. Thus, it should pave the way for the recent outperformance to hang on firmly, and not devolve into another potentially disastrous selloff, as investors scrutinize whether the recent surge has been overstated.

Intel Foundry's Bloodshed Far From Over

Intel's Q3 earnings scorecard demonstrates that execution has clearly improved under the leadership of CEO Lip-Bu Tan. It corresponds to Wall Street's outlook that INTC's margins should have bottomed in late 2024, although foundry continues to be a massive margin bleeder, recording almost -55% in segment operating margin in the third quarter.

Nevertheless, encouraging signals from the ongoing ramp up of Intel's 18A indicates that the low watermark reached last year should be a thing of the past. Accordingly, Intel had already communicated confident guidance in October, as it telegraphed that Panther Lake (based on the 18A process) had moved into volume production, highlighting the positive cadence implied in its roadmap through 2027.

And of course, I had already enunciated the confidence boost that Intel has been afforded by the recent Nvidia investment (which the firm expects to close in 2025), while also having the U.S. government's as one of its cornerstone shareholders. Is Intel foundry ready to prove that 18A could finally be the moment for it to mark a monumental turnaround yet?

Well, I think it's too early for us to ascertain, but the recent progress augurs well as it works on an x86-based chip with Nvidia, which speaks volumes of the company's sticky x86 architecture ecosystem. And management is right to highlight that even as the potential data center capacity is expected to explode multifold through 2030, CPUs are still expected to play a pivotal role in the buildout, providing the runway for Intel to partake in the AI inflection, even though it hasn't quite validated its ability to compete against Nvidia, AMD (AMD) or even Broadcom (AVGO) when it comes to supplying OpenAI (OPEN) with the most cutting-edge of AI chips.

Yet, I thought Qualcomm's (QCOM) recent AI chip unveiling was telling, showing that investors shouldn't write off the chip design capabilities of the semiconductor behemoths like Intel, notwithstanding the struggles that it has been through.

Intel's liquidity and capital allocation strategies are expected to be a lot more disciplined, despite expecting to post a higher CapEx range for 2025 to the tune of $27 billion. Nevertheless, it does appear that the delayed AI PC ramp could experience a much-needed liftoff from 2026/27, as Intel underscored what every investor arguably wanted to hear: the company is supply constrained. It suggests that Intel's demand dynamics have likely been bolstered, which should help to continue paving the way for its operating margins to recover, even though we should be cautious in trying to ascribe too much optimism this early into the ramp.

Intel: Margin Worries Should Subside, But Don't Bank On A Hockey Stick Inflection

While the optionality of having Intel foundry be a positive margins driver in the future is alluring, I believe the market won't be fooled into putting too much hopium into the thesis for now, until validated. And with TSMC (TSM) being so dominant and relied upon right now by the leading chip designers and the hyperscalers, I don't assess it as reasonable for us (yet) to give the benefit of the doubt about the plausible revival in this segment for now.

Hence, while Wall Street forecasts that Intel's CapEx growth should slow down markedly through 2027, the ongoing margin recovery will likely still be driven by the positive outlook in the PC business, while being impeded to a lesser extent due to the ongoing losses in its foundry business. In other words, I believe there's a ceiling on how much operating leverage gains Intel could squeeze out from its unprofitable foundry business, while still relying on a relatively mature PC market to lead the overall recovery.

Buy Or Sell INTC Stock?

And when we consider the incredible surge that saw INTC take out levels last observed in early 2024, I think the momentum is clearly too fast and too furious. Obviously, investors are banking on the renewed vigor underlining its narrative, with the investments inked with the U.S. government and Nvidia as the bedrock of its recent gains.

Because, while I concur that Intel's Q3 release has shown us that execution appears to be firmly on the right track amid a relatively sanguine market right now, I'm not sure whether INTC's >90x forward earnings multiple is truly justified. It seems like the market is betting on an even more spectacular restoration of its business fundamentals through 2027, or even the potential gain of crucial foundry customers due to the assumed lack of foundry capacity to deliver the 250GW in data center capacity that OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is reportedly gunning for.

While these are certainly pivotal aspects in Intel's incredible turnaround story to salivate over, I think the market could have taken their exuberance way too far, as there's still little for Intel to show for in these businesses at the current moment, or even for the foreseeable future.

I don't anticipate Intel announcing a gargantuan partnership with OpenAI at the moment, while hyperscalers are arguably not going to send their custom chips to Intel to fab, if Nvidia isn't leading the way as a flagship customer to validate Intel's production yields first.

These are enough reasons for me to urge investors who didn't manage to join INTC's stellar ascent to sit out, while contemplating other higher-quality setups among its peers.

Rating: Maintain "Hold."

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.
